OSS/J TT RI

 

OSS/J Reference Implementation (RI) for the Trouble Ticketing API v1.0.2


This document describes the installation of the OSS/J TT Reference Implementation (RI) J2EE application servers delivered with the J2EE-SDK v1.4.
This package also contains the source code of the RI and ant tasks to build the RI from the sources.

This document contains the following sections:

  • Overview
  • Deploying the RI
  • Compiling and Assembling the OSS/J RI 
  • Troubleshooting


Overview

This Reference Implementation provides an implementation of the JVT and XVT communication profile as specified in the OSS/J Trouble Ticketing API specification version 1.0. This package includes:
  • This documentation
  • Prepared jars for direct deployment
  • Source code
  • Ant scripts for building jars from the source code and deploying the RI to the application server.
This RI uses parts of the OSS/J RI for the QOS/FM API version 1.0. The source code for this RI is not included but can be downloaded from the OSS/J web sites.
The deployment scripts which are delivered with this package are tailored for installing this RI on the J2EE 1.4 Reference Implementation. This RI should be runnable on any J2EE compliant application server, deployment on other application servers is not supported by this package.
The Reference Implementation uses a relational database to store the trouble ticket data. This documentation describes how to use the TT RI with the Pointbase RDBMS delivered with the J2EE-SDK 1.4.



Deploying the RI

Command Line Based Deployment describes how to manually register the application in a Application Server using a Command Line Interface (CLI). This is the fastest means of deploying the application.



Setting up the environment

In order to successfully deploy and run the RI, Database resources (PointBase) needs to be setup with the Application Server. If you want to run the RI with the Oracle database, please refer to (oracle sample in the j2EE sdk sample package) for configuration steps.

Prerequisite:

Add <j2ee sdk 1.4 install_dir>/bin to your path and configure the <install_dir>/common.properties file according to <j2ee sdk 1.4 install_dir>
(or copy the common.properties from <j2ee sdk 1.4 install_dir>/samples to <install_dir>)

<>

 NOTE: You must start and configure the Database.

Starting PointBase

The database server can be easily started by performing one of the following actions:

Windows Platforms:

PointBase installed with the application server: Start -> Programs -> Sun Microsystems -> J2EE 1.4 SDK -> Start PointBase

PointBase downloaded and installed separately:
<j2ee sdk 1.4 install_dir>/pointbase/tools/serveroption/startserver.bat

UNIX Platforms:

PointBase installed with the application server:
<j2ee sdk 1.4 install_dir>/pointbase/tools/serveroption/startserver.sh

PointBase downloaded and installed separately:
<j2ee sdk 1.4 install_dir>/pointbase/tools/serveroption/startserver.sh

Alternatively, if you copied the PointBase Server files to your own directory, execute the startserver script from that location.

Once you execute the startup script, you will see the following text in either a command window or at the UNIX terminal prompt:

    Server started, listening on port 9092, display level: 0 ...
    >

To stop the server, enter quit at the > prompt.

Don't Need A Console Window? On UNIX, if you want to run the PointBase server in the background, you can edit the startserver.sh script and place the option "/noconsole" at the end of the command line.

.../java -classpath ./lib/pbembedded.jar;./lib/pbtools.jar com.pointbase.net.netServer /port:9092 /noconsole

The jar file pbembedded.jar and pbtools.jar are for PointBase 4.5 installation. You may have to use different jar file depending upon your PointBase installation.

Use "&" at the end of the StartServer.sh command to run the server in the background.

./startserver.sh &
[1] 26418

If you want to set traces on the Pointbase server, you can edit the startserver.sh script and place the option "/d:3" at the end of the command line:

.../java -classpath ./lib/pbembedded.jar;./lib/pbtools.jar com.pointbase.net.netServer /port:9092 /d:3
or
./startserver.sh /d:3 &

See the PointBase server documentation in the following location for more information on starting and stopping the server:

<j2ee sdk 1.4 install_dir>/pointbase/docs/


You can now deploy  the application.

Stopping PointBase

To stop the server, enter quit at the > prompt.

Executing SQL Statements with PointBase

The easiest means of performing these tasks is to use the PointBase Console GUI to execute SQL statements found in the .sql files within the src/sql/ directory.

To start the Console, follow these instructions:

Windows Platforms:

PointBase installed with the application server: Execute
<j2ee sdk 1.4 install_dir>\pointbase\tools\serveroption\startconsole.bat

PointBase downloaded and installed separately: <j2ee sdk 1.4 install_dir>/pointbase>\tools\serveroption\startconsole.bat

UNIX Platforms:

PointBase installed with the application server: Execute <install_dir>/pointbase/tools/serveroption/startconsole.sh

PointBase downloaded and installed separately: <pointbase_install_dir>/tools/serveroption/startconsole.sh

The Console appears.

Note: To connect to the database, select DBA -> Connect to Database. (Note: Default user name and password for Pointbase is PBPUBLIC / PBPUBLIC)

Enter the following information for the samples database installed with the application server:

  • Driver: use the default value as provided.
  • URL: jdbc:pointbase:server://localhost/pointbase
  • check the box "Create new Data base" (if it is the time)
  • User and Password: use values as appropriate for the sample of interest:
Application User Password
OSS/J RI PBPUBLIC PBPUBLIC

Once connected to the database, you can enter SQL statements in the top portion of the window and the results can be viewed in the lower portion. SQL statements can be entered individually or as a sequence of statements from a file.

Select File -> Open and open <install_dir>/src/sql/pointbase/pointbase.create.sql directory, as provided with the OSS/J RI.

Note:

If a single statement has to be executed, then enter the SQL statement and select the menu option SQL -> Execute to execute the statement.

If a sequence of statements is to be executed, use the menu option SQL -> Execute all.

Prerequisites to deployment. 

Change server security to add write permision to server.policy
Modify <j2ee sdk 1.4 install-dir>/domains/domain1/config/server.policy from
     permission java.util.PropertyPermission "*", "read";
   to
     permission java.util.PropertyPermission "*", "read,write";

Modify server.policy file to allow the RMI communication with the backend eis application.
   permission java.net.SocketPermission "*:0-65535", "accept, resolve, connect, listen";
   permission java.security.AllPermission;
For example,
grant {
        permission java.lang.RuntimePermission  "loadLibrary.*";
        permission java.lang.RuntimePermission  "queuePrintJob";
        permission java.net.SocketPermission    "*:0-65535", "accept, resolve, connect, listen";
        permission java.io.FilePermission       "<<ALL FILES>>", "read,write";
        permission java.util.PropertyPermission "*", "read,write";
        permission java.lang.RuntimePermission  "modifyThreadGroup";
        permission java.security.AllPermission;
}; 


Start the application Server using the command "asadmin start-domain"

Command Line Based Deployment


Since a complete .ear file is supplied, the fastest means of setting up the application is to use the command line utilities as described in this section.

The pre-built xxxx.ear file is an Enterprise Archive file that contains the Java Archive (JAR) files of the application.

Deploy using the asant script.


Using the asant Script



    2. Go to the src directory of the sample:

    <install_dir>/src


    3. Execute the "asant deploy" command. This will configure and deploy the RI to the Application server.

    For re-deployment the following command could be used independently
    Target Function
    compile Compiles all Java source code.
    war Assembles the WAR file in <sample_dir>/assemble/war/.
    ear Assembles the EAR file in <sample_dir>/assemble/ear/.
    core (default) Compiles all sources, builds stubs/skeletons and assembles EJB[tm] JAR, WAR and EAR files. This is the default target for all build.xml files shipped in the application server.
    javadocs Creates Java docs in <sample_dir>/javadocs
    all Builds both core and javadocs, verifies, registers resources and deploys app.
    deploy Registers resources, deploys app, but does not install Javadocs.
    deploy_ear Application deployment only. No resource registration.
    verify
    		 Verifies application binaries.
    undeploy Removes the deployed application from application server and remove resources.
    undeploy_ear
    		 Removes the deployed application from application server
    clean Removes <appname>/build/ and <appname>/assemble/ content.
    setup
    		 Configure the Application server (create JDBC and JMS resources)
    unsetup
    		 Remove resources from the Application server (delete JDBC and JMS resources)

Verifying Deployment

 

As an optional step, you can use the Application Server Administration Tool to verify that the application has been registered.

To verify the registration of the application:



    2. Execute the asadmin command to look at applications deployed with a server instance. You see ossj_qos_ri as one of the listed applications.

    asadmin list-components  --user <user-name> --password <password> 



    3. Or navigate the Admin tool GUI to Applications-->Enterprise Applications.


    Click Enterprise Applications on the left frame menu to display a list of applications deployed on the server.




Compiling and Assembling the Application

This Command Line Based Compilation and Assembly procedure describes how to assemble and compile the sample using a Command Line Interface (CLI).


Command Line Based Compilation and Assembly


To rebuild the entire application from scratch:


    2. Compile and Assemble.

    Execute the "asant compile ear" command under <install_dir>/src/

    The default target core is executed to rebuild the .ear file.
    The command: asant compile ear can also be used.


    2. Deploy the application.

    When you have re-created the RI from scratch, proceed to Deploying the application.


    3. Clean the RI project area.

    Execute the "asant clean" command to remove the RI's assemble and build directories.

    Now you are ready to use this .ear file for deployment.


Generating Javadocs


To understand sample application source code better, you can refer to the related javadocs. To generate javadocs, run the command

asant javadocs

or

asant all

After javadocs are generated, you can access them at

<install_dir>/javadocs/index.html



Troubleshooting


If you encounter problems when running the application, review the log files at <j2ee sdk 1.4 install-dir>/domains/<domain>/logs/server.log to see what went wrong.

Make certain that you run asant undeploy before redeploying this sample to make sure that all modules are undeployed and the resources are disabled.
